categories.name: Popular culture, entertainment and the arts

subCategories.name: Popular culture, entertainment and the arts - General

articles.title: Breast-shaped hill
articles.teaserText: Laid bare in many places around the world. May have given their name to Manchester.

articles.title: Folly
articles.teaserText: Buildings prized for their uselessness.

articles.title: Gravity hill
articles.teaserText: A hill that gives the illusion of objects rolling up it.

articles.title: Pizza farm
articles.teaserText: All the ingredients of pizza, grown in one convenient location!

articles.title: Rocket garden
articles.teaserText: Landscaping and rocketry, together at last.

articles.title: Spite house
articles.teaserText: Various houses built solely out of spite for their neighbors.

articles.title: Valeriepieris circle
articles.teaserText: You either live inside the circle or outside. Even though you live inside.

articles.title: Bir Tawil
articles.teaserText: One of the few places on Earth not claimed by any country. An American trekked there and claimed it in 2014 as the Kingdom of North Sudan so he could make his daughter a princess.

articles.title: Congo Pedicle
articles.teaserText: What happens when a tyrannical king decides he wants to hunt game in a swamp.

articles.title: Gaet'ale Pond
articles.teaserText: A small lake in Ethiopia that was created in 2005 after an earthquake. It's not bitter, it's just really, really salty.

articles.title: Jacob's Ladder (Saint Helena)
articles.teaserText: It's all very downhill from here.

articles.title: Lake Nyos
articles.teaserText: A lake in northwestern Cameroon that exploded in 1986, killing 1,746 people. One of 3 known exploding lakes, the others being Lake Monoun and Lake Kivu.

articles.title: Oklo Mine
articles.teaserText: The former site of the world's only natural nuclear fission reactors.

articles.title: Peñón de Vélez de la Gomera
articles.teaserText: A rock on the Moroccan coast connected to the mainland by an 80-metre-wide (260 ft) tombolo; it is owned by Spain.

articles.title: Republic of Benin (1967)
articles.teaserText: One of the shortest-lived states in history, it was independent for only seven hours (07:00 to 14:00 on 19 September 1967).

articles.title: Blood Falls
articles.teaserText: A naturally occurring plume of saltwater that is blood red thanks to its high iron oxide content.

articles.title: Mawson Peak
articles.teaserText: The tallest mountain in Australia is not on the mainland, but on a barren, uninhabited island more than 3,800 kilometres (2,400 mi) away.

articles.title: McMurdo Dry Valleys
articles.teaserText: An area of Antarctica that a) contains an extremely saline body of water and b) has not experienced rainfall for over two million years.

articles.title: Marie Byrd Land
articles.teaserText: The largest unclaimed territory in the world. Notable for being bigger than Mongolia, having one of Antarctica's biggest human bases, and being the setting of the 1951 film The Thing.

articles.title: Artsvashen
articles.teaserText: An Armenian town surrounded and controlled by Azerbaijan. One of a number of similar towns on this border; others include Yukhari Askipara, Barxudarlı and Karki.

articles.title: Atar, Padang Ganting
articles.teaserText: An Indonesian village with a monument resembling a photocopier.

articles.title: Camp Bonifas
articles.teaserText: The bunkers on this golf course feature machine-guns and landmines.

articles.title: Dahala Khagrabari
articles.teaserText: India inside Bangladesh inside India inside Bangladesh. Formerly the only third-order enclave in the world.

articles.title: Darvaza gas crater
articles.teaserText: A flaming, 70 m (230 ft) wide, 30 m (98 ft) deep crater in the middle of the Karakum Desert, on fire since 1971.

articles.title: Dhekelia Power Station
articles.teaserText: A Cypriot power station that provides power to a British military base that surrounds it.

articles.title: Diomede Islands
articles.teaserText: Two islands in the Bering Strait separated by 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) and 21 hours' time difference.

articles.title: Gangkhar Puensum
articles.teaserText: The tallest mountain nobody has ever summitted, as the Bhutanese government has prohibited mountaineering since 2003.

articles.title: Gate Tower Building
articles.teaserText: A skyscraper in Japan that has a highway offramp passing through its fifth, sixth and seventh floors.

articles.title: Hallstatt (China)
articles.teaserText: An ongoing replica construction of a town in Austria.

articles.title: Hanazono Room
articles.teaserText: An indoor swimming pool in Japan used as the site for many pornographic films.

articles.title: Jewish Autonomous Oblast
articles.teaserText: In the depth of Eastern Siberia there's a place with street names in Yiddish, even though 99% of its population is not Jewish.

articles.title: Kai Tak Airport
articles.teaserText: A major international airport closed in 1998 where planes literally almost crashed constantly into the city due to a right-hand turn over the city.

articles.title: Karni Mata Temple
articles.teaserText: A marble temple famous for 25,000 revered black rats that live in the temple who are considered the ancestors of Charans.

articles.title: Kijong-dong
articles.teaserText: A village in North Korea characterized by mainstream media as a North Korean propaganda Potemkin village.

articles.title: Korea Central Zoo
articles.teaserText: A zoo with such wondrous animals as a chimpanzee with a smoking habit, a parrot that sings the praises of Kim Il-sung, and some of the few legally owned dogs in Pyongyang.

articles.title: Kowloon Walled City
articles.teaserText: A former enclave in the city of Hong Kong, known for lawlessness and extremely cramped conditions before it was destroyed and turned into a park.

articles.title: Living root bridge
articles.teaserText: Double-decker suspension bridges formed of living plant aerial roots of rubber fig trees by tree shaping common in the southern part of the Northeast Indian state of Meghalaya.

articles.title: Love Land
articles.teaserText: An erotic-themed sculpture park on Jeju island in South Korea.

articles.title: Nahwa
articles.teaserText: One of only eight counter-enclaves (enclaves of enclaves).

articles.title: Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic
articles.teaserText: A landlocked exclave of Azerbaijan (it is surrounded by three different countries rather than only one, so it is not an enclave).

articles.title: Ōkunoshima
articles.teaserText: An island between the Japanese home islands of Honshu and Shikoku formerly home to a chemical weapons plant in WW2, now home to a huge population of feral but largely tame rabbits.

articles.title: Omsk Metro
articles.teaserText: A metro system with only one station and a total length of zero kilometres.

articles.title: Peanut Hole
articles.teaserText: A delightfully named patch of ocean in the Sea of Okhotsk that is totally surrounded by Russia's EEZ but not inside it. Often the subject of foreign overfishing.

articles.title: Rednaxela Terrace
articles.teaserText: A street in Hong Kong, whose name was reportedly reversed due to a clerical error

articles.title: Robot Building
articles.teaserText: That's not a giant robot looming in Bangkok; it's just a bank's headquarters

articles.title: Ryugyong Hotel
articles.teaserText: Once, it would have been the world's tallest hotel – except it lacked windows, fittings, or fixtures for over twenty years.

articles.title: San Serriffe
articles.teaserText: A lesser-known island in the Indian Ocean, subject of the April 1, 1977 Guardian.

articles.title: Sansha
articles.teaserText: A disputed prefecture-level city in Hainan consisting of a collection of atolls and reefs throughout the South China Sea.

articles.title: Seikan Tunnel Tappi Shakō Line
articles.teaserText: The closed funicular that connects an underground train station inside the Seikan Tunnel with a museum.

articles.title: Shingō, Aomori
articles.teaserText: A town in Japan that is (supposedly) home to the tomb of Jesus. The story behind the supposed tomb is even odder.

articles.title: Soʻx District
articles.teaserText: An exclave of Uzbekistan enclaved within Kyrgyzstan with a 99% Tajik population.

articles.title: Tashirojima
articles.teaserText: An island in Japan notable for being full of cats.

articles.title: Tomb of Suleyman Shah
articles.teaserText: One of the burial sites of the first Ottoman emperor's grandfather is part of Turkey despite being 27 kilometres (17 mi) south of the country's border with Syria.

articles.title: Tsu Station
articles.teaserText: By kana, the tersest railway station in Japan, serving the capital of an almost as terse prefecture. By stroke count, the tersest in the world. By transliteration, only second-tersest.

articles.title: Wonderland Amusement Park
articles.teaserText: The largest abandoned amusement park in Asia.

articles.title: X-Seed 4000
articles.teaserText: The tallest building ever designed, standing 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) tall and housing 500,000 to 1,000,000 people on 800 floors. It is, however, 'never meant to be built'.

articles.title: Yongning Pagoda
articles.teaserText: A 6th-century pagoda that was possibly the tallest structure in the world until it was destroyed by lightning 18 years after its completion.

articles.title: Zheltuga Republic
articles.teaserText: An illegal gold mining settlement that developed into a thriving unrecognised country, only surviving because the Chinese government was unaware that it existed.

articles.title: Argleton
articles.teaserText: A non-existent town in Lancashire, England that appeared on Google Maps.

articles.title: Barcelona Supercomputing Center
articles.teaserText: A supercomputer in a medieval chapel.

articles.title: Barentsburg
articles.teaserText: A completely Russian town, inhabited by Russians, with Russian buildings, supported financially by the Russian government, located in Norway.

articles.title: Barra Airport
articles.teaserText: An airport that only operates when the tide allows.

articles.title: Battersea Power Station station
articles.teaserText: A train station named after a non-train station

articles.title: Beans and Bacon mine
articles.teaserText: With such little ventilation, visitors may want to avoid any source of ignition. Nearby mines are not to be outdone and have the following names: Mule Spinner, Frogs Hole, Cackle Mackle, and Wanton Legs.

articles.title: Berlin Brandenburg Airport
articles.teaserText: A construction-finished but unfinished in other areas airport in Berlin. Construction was finished in 2012; however, the opening date was repeatedly pushed back as the fire suppression system was installed incorrectly. It finally opened in October 2020.

articles.title: Bielefeld conspiracy
articles.teaserText: The Bielefeld-Verschwörung tries to hide the horrible truth about a city in Westphalia, Germany that doesn't exist... well, maybe.

articles.title: Brennender Berg
articles.teaserText: A German coal mine on fire since 1668.

articles.title: The Broomway
articles.teaserText: The most dangerous path in the world? Would you join a hundred others who died walking the invisible path?

articles.title: Brusio spiral viaduct
articles.teaserText: The title says it all, really.

articles.title: Büsingen am Hochrhein
articles.teaserText: A German town that is fully contained within Switzerland.

articles.title: Butt Hole Road
articles.teaserText: A tiny residential street in the UK that was so infamous for its name that it became a tourist attraction.

articles.title: Carpatho-Ukraine
articles.teaserText: The third shortest-lived state in history (see Benin Republic in Nigeria); it was independent for only 24 hours.

articles.title: Cerne Abbas Giant
articles.teaserText: An indecent chalk man in the English countryside.

articles.title: Ferdinand Cheval
articles.teaserText: A postman, who, for thirty-three years, collected stones while making his rounds and used them to build a surreal Palais Idéal ('Ideal Palace') of astonishing proportions and intricate detail.

articles.title: Colletto Fava
articles.teaserText: A 1,500-metre (4,900 ft) hill with a 61-metre (200 ft) stuffed pink bunny on top.

articles.title: Ebenezer Place, Wick
articles.teaserText: The world's shortest street.

articles.title: Fallen Monument Park
articles.teaserText: A Russian park best known for its toppled statues.

articles.title: Ferdinandea Island
articles.teaserText: The island that disappeared. And rose again. And sank again. And rose again. And sank again.

articles.title: Flannan Isles Lighthouse
articles.teaserText: Located on Eilean Mór, this lighthouse to the west of Scotland is the subject of an enduring mystery over the disappearance of its keepers in 1900.

articles.title: Forest swastika
articles.teaserText: A gigantic swastika made of larch trees that went unnoticed for nearly sixty years.

articles.title: Gammalsvenskby
articles.teaserText: A Swedish village, populated by Swedes, who speak an ancient Swedish dialect, in Ukraine.

articles.title: Icelandic Phallological Museum
articles.teaserText: A museum in Iceland solely devoted to the collection of penis specimens and penis-related art.

articles.title: JASON reactor
articles.teaserText: The only nuclear reactor in a 17th-century building.

articles.title: Leaning Tower of Suurhusen
articles.teaserText: Beating the world-famous Leaning Tower of Pisa by 1.22 degrees.

articles.title: Llandegley International Airport
articles.teaserText: When is an international airport not an international airport? When it's not an airport at all.

articles.title: Llanfairpwllgwyngyll
articles.teaserText: Or Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch, if you want to get technical.

articles.title: Magic Roundabout
articles.teaserText: Only in the United Kingdom would you find a large roundabout with six mini-roundabouts. (Not to be confused with the 'Magic Roundabout's in Colchester, Swindon or High Wycombe – or, for that matter, this 'Magic Roundabout'.)

articles.title: Märket
articles.teaserText: A lighthouse built on this island led to a redefinition of the border between Sweden and Finland.

articles.title: Metro-2
articles.teaserText: A purported secret metro line in Moscow.

articles.title: Monte Kaolino
articles.teaserText: A ski resort without snow.

articles.title: Mount Athos
articles.teaserText: An autonomous polity in Greece home to 20 monasteries, notable for being the only political subdivision in the world in which women (as well as female animals) are prohibited from entering for any reason.

articles.title: Neutral Moresnet
articles.teaserText: A tiny European region – approximately 1.4 square miles (3.6 km2) – that existed for a century as neutral territory between Germany and Belgium.

articles.title: Newhaven Marine railway station
articles.teaserText: A railway station that was technically open between 2006 and 2020, despite (a) no passenger trains serving the station during that time, (b) an inability to buy tickets to the station and (c) the station itself being demolished in 2017.

articles.title: Other World Kingdom
articles.teaserText: A micronation and BDSM resort whose ultimate goal is 'absolute matriarchy' – for all men to be enslaved by women.

articles.title: Papa Westray Airport
articles.teaserText: An unassuming coastal airport in the Orkney Isles, where you can take a scenic flight to the nearby island of Westray, and enjoy all 47 seconds to 1 minute and 30 seconds of it.

articles.title: Paradiskullen
articles.teaserText: A ski jumping hill with a landing area that goes under one of Sweden's busiest railroads.

articles.title: Pheasant Island
articles.teaserText: An uninhabited river island which switches sovereignty between France and Spain every six months.

articles.title: Principality of Sealand
articles.teaserText: A micronation located 6 miles (9.7 km) off the coast of Suffolk, England whose population rarely exceeds ten.

articles.title: Reality Checkpoint
articles.teaserText: A lamppost with its own name.

articles.title: Röstigraben
articles.teaserText: The 'Coarsely Grated Potato Ditch' in Switzerland, dividing Swiss-German and Swiss-French cuisine.

articles.title: Saatse Boot
articles.teaserText: A piece of Russian territory through which a 900-metre (3,000 ft) stretch of Estonian road passes. Although people are allowed to drive on the road without a permit or visa, it is prohibited to travel on foot, or to stop the vehicle for any reason.

articles.title: Schwerbelastungskörper
articles.teaserText: A piece of Nazi architecture in Berlin, built with the sole purpose of being heavy.

articles.title: Scottish Court in the Netherlands
articles.teaserText: A former Dutch NATO base called Camp Zeist was briefly ceded to Scotland to enable the trial of the Pan Am Flight 103 bombers.

articles.title: Sedlec Ossuary
articles.teaserText: A Christian chapel decorated by the bones of approximately 40,000 people.

articles.title: Sexi (Phoenician colony)
articles.teaserText: An ancient ruins, also known as Sex or Ex, with several Roman-era suburbs, including Pænis, Socordia and Villa Fatuus Maximus.

articles.title: Shell Grotto, Margate
articles.teaserText: A grotto with a mosaic of 4.6 million seashells, hidden underneath a backyard. Nobody knows who built it, when, or for what purpose.

articles.title: Smallest House in Great Britain
articles.teaserText: Only 5.49 square metres (59.1 sq ft) in size, in North Wales.

articles.title: Sovereign Military Order of Malta
articles.teaserText: A sovereign state with no land? How is that possible?

articles.title: Spreuerhofstraße
articles.teaserText: The world's narrowest street.

articles.title: Svalbard Global Seed Vault
articles.teaserText: If a global famine occurs, you better hope you live in Svalbard.

articles.title: Uffington White Horse
articles.teaserText: A giant chalk figure that has to be hit with hammers regularly to maintain it.

articles.title: UFO-Memorial Ängelholm
articles.teaserText: A memorial to a reputed UFO landing in Sweden.

articles.title: Unst Bus Shelter
articles.teaserText: The only of its kind on the island of Unst, Shetland. It is periodically refurnished and contains a sofa and TV.

articles.title: Vennbahn
articles.teaserText: A disused railway in Belgium which separates five pieces of Germany from the rest of Germany.

articles.title: Weißwurstäquator
articles.teaserText: The 'White Sausage Equator' in Germany.

articles.title: White's
articles.teaserText: London's oldest and most famous gentleman's club had several famous people as members, including King Charles III, Prince William, former prime minister David Cameron and so on. The club is pretty much top secret, so yes, the English illuminati definitely aren't lurking and drinking tea there. Also, no girls are allowed.

articles.title: Whip-Ma-Whop-Ma-Gate
articles.teaserText: And the best street name has to go to this street in York, England. Also said to be the shortest street in the city too!

articles.title: Wooden Spoons Museum
articles.teaserText: A museum with the largest collection of wooden spoons in the world, ranging from 3,500 to over 6,000. Ladles and 500 erasers can also be found!

articles.title: Željava Air Base
articles.teaserText: An abandoned air base, located on the border between Croatia and Bosnia, that's almost entirely underground.

articles.title: Aroma of Tacoma
articles.teaserText: 'What an incredible smell you've discovered' could have been this Washington city's motto.

articles.title: Aquarius Reef Base
articles.teaserText: A real-live underwater labolatory.

articles.title: Agloe, New York
articles.teaserText: A fictional town in New York. Originally a phantom settlement, created as a copyright trap for a mapmaker, that ended up developing into an actual landmark.

articles.title: Alcohol and Drug Abuse Lake
articles.teaserText: Supposedly named after the treatment center nearby.

articles.title: Badlands Guardian
articles.teaserText: A natural topographic feature in Alberta, Canada, which, when viewed from above, looks remarkably like a human wearing a Native American headdress and earbuds.

articles.title: Beatosu and Goblu
articles.teaserText: Two non-existent towns that appeared on Michigan's official highway map as a reference to the University of Michigan and its rival, Ohio State University.

articles.title: Bubbly Creek
articles.teaserText: The branch of the Chicago River that was so contaminated with blood from the Stock Yards that it gained this appetizing moniker.

articles.title: Bullfrog County, Nevada
articles.teaserText: A former county in Nevada established around a mountain which was to become a radioactive waste disposal site. As of 2022, it is the only uninhabited county-equivalent to ever be created in the United States.

articles.title: Canusa Street
articles.teaserText: A road that's in both Canada and USA.

articles.title: Capitol Hill's mystery soda machine
articles.teaserText: A machine that offered rare drinks and nobody knows who operated it. It was in operation from the 1990s to 2018, when it disappeared and a note was left saying: “Went for a walk”.

articles.title: Cat Girl Manor
articles.teaserText: A manor described as 'the Playboy Mansion of the kitten play community'.

articles.title: Centralia, Pennsylvania
articles.teaserText: A town that's been on fire since 1962.

articles.title: Clinton Road (New Jersey)
articles.teaserText: In addition to having the longest traffic light in the country, the road is also notorious for reported occurrences of paranormal activity.

articles.title: Colma, California
articles.teaserText: A town where the dead outnumber the living by 1000 to 1.

articles.title: Crush, Texas
articles.teaserText: A temporary 'city' established as the site of an 1896 publicity stunt, a staged train wreck. The wreck unexpectedly caused two deaths and numerous injuries among spectators.

articles.title: Corporation Trust Center (CT Corporation)
articles.teaserText: A small single-story building where over 285,000 companies, or over 15% of all companies in the United States, are legally based.

articles.title: Dixie Square Mall
articles.teaserText: A shopping mall that stood abandoned for over twice as long as it was in business until it was finally demolished in 2012. It was featured in the 1980 film The Blues Brothers and became a popular target for urban explorers.

articles.title: Dorset, Minnesota
articles.teaserText: A town that, on multiple occasions, has had a child as their 'mayor'.

articles.title: Dude Chilling Park
articles.teaserText: Originally a sign placed in a Vancouver park as a prank, now officially recognized public art.

articles.title: Ernst Thälmann Island
articles.teasertext: An island off the coast of Cuba that was (sort of) ceded to East Germany and thus (sort of) remains part of East Germany, which doesn't exist anymore (sort of).

articles.title: Fenelon Place Elevator
articles.teasertext: The shortest and steepest railroad in the world, (supposedly) located in a town of around 60,000 people.

articles.title: Florence Y'all Water Tower
articles.teasertext: A Northern Kentucky town's unique "welcome" sign.

articles.title: Gann Valley, South Dakota
articles.teasertext: The county seat of Buffalo County, South Dakota, despite nearby Fort Thompson having a population more than 90 times larger than Gann Valley.

articles.title: Greater Green River Intergalactic Spaceport
articles.teasertext: Consists entirely of a deeply rutted unmanned strip of soil/gravel and a windsock.

articles.title: Gum Wall
articles.teasertext: A brick wall in Seattle burdened by chewing gum. Cleaned in 2015, only to be turned into a memorial for Paris.

articles.title: Hans Island
articles.teasertext: A deserted Arctic island fought over by Canada and the Kingdom of Denmark for decades. The 2022 settlement created a land border between a North American and a European country.

articles.title: Hawaii 2
articles.teasertext: A quaint island in Maine purchased by Cards Against Humanity in 2014.

articles.title: Hess Triangle
articles.teasertext: This used to be part of a bigger plot of land but a road destroyed it but the planners couldn't plan correctly so it left this piece of land.

articles.title: Horace Burgess's Treehouse
articles.teasertext: A tree house built by a minister who claimed to have received a vision from God.

articles.title: Interstate 180 (Wyoming)
articles.teasertext: An Interstate Highway that isn't really a freeway at all.

articles.title: Interstate 19
articles.teasertext: The only U.S. highway marked in metric units, a relic of a historical push for metrication.

articles.title: Island of California
articles.teasertext: The third-largest U.S. state was formerly an island – at least on paper.

articles.title: Island of the Dolls
articles.teasertext: Located in Mexico City, this is an island full of broken and deteriorated dolls of various styles and colors, originally placed by the former owner of the island.

articles.title: Jackass Flats
articles.teasertext: The aptly named test site for the world's first and only nuclear-powered rocket engines.

articles.title: Jerimoth Hill
articles.teasertext: The highest natural point in Rhode Island. For years, one of the toughest highpoints in the U.S. to scale, not because of its 812-foot (247 m) height, but because of an angry old man who lived nearby.

articles.title: Just Room Enough Island
articles.teasertext: This island is about one-thirteenth of an acre in size but that didn't stop the Sizeland family from building a house on it.

articles.title: Landsat Island
articles.teasertext: A lonesome island with a frankly humorous tale.

articles.title: List of gaps in Interstate Highways
articles.teasertext: Traffic-lighted intersections, drawbridges, and other oddities in the Interstate Highway System which violate the standards.

articles.title: List of Las Vegas casinos that never opened
articles.teasertext: What happened on the drawing board stayed on the drawing board.

articles.title: London Bridge
articles.teasertext: An over century year old authentic English bridge...that now resides in the middle of the desert.

articles.title: M-185 (Michigan highway)
articles.teasertext: The only state highway in the country that bans motor vehicles. It's also the only state highway to not have an accident until 2005.

articles.title: Mary Ellis grave
articles.teasertext: A grave that found itself in the middle of a movie theater parking lot.

articles.title: Pyramid mausoleums in North America
articles.teasertext: Arizona Governor George Hunt will hereafter be addressed as "Pharaoh George I".

articles.title: Point Roberts, Washington
articles.teasertext: When defining international boundaries, sometimes a straight line isn't the best solution.

articles.title: Polar Bear Holding Facility
articles.teasertext: A prison for polar bears.

articles.title: Prada Marfa, Texas
articles.teasertext: For your luxury shopping bug, a Prada store in the desert.

articles.title: Rabbit Hash, Kentucky
articles.teasertext: A town whose mayors, since 1998, have all been dogs.

articles.title: Raising of Chicago
articles.teasertext: During the 1850s, the city was raised on jacks, building by building.

articles.title: Rough and Ready, California
articles.teasertext: A currently populated, unincorporated mining town in the United States that seceded from the Union in 1850, forming the "Great Republic of Rough and Ready". Secession was rescinded less than three months later when its citizens noticed that they could not celebrate U.S. independence.

articles.title: Republic of Indian Stream
articles.teasertext: An area of land in northern New Hampshire that was an independent country from 1832 to 1835.

articles.title: Republic of Molossia
articles.teasertext: A 34-person micronation in Nevada which takes the meaning of the phrase "a man's home is his castle" to new extremes.

articles.title: Río Rico, Tamaulipas
articles.teasertext: A city that was ceded by the United States to Mexico in 1977 due to an earlier diversion of the Rio Grande.

articles.title: Rock N Roll McDonald's
articles.teasertext: A rock 'n roll-themed McDonald's restaurant located in Chicago, famous for being the subject of a song by outsider musician Wesley Willis.

articles.title: Santa Claus, Arizona
articles.teasertext: In Mohave County, visit an abandoned tourist trap deep in the desert where Santa Claus, of all people, allegedly resides!

articles.title: Sam Kee Building
articles.teasertext: Known as the world's narrowest commercial building.

articles.title: State of Scott
articles.teasertext: Scott County in northern Tennessee seceded and formed its own state in opposition to Tennessee joining the Confederacy. It remained this way for over a century until it rejoined Tennessee in 1986.

articles.title: Texas State Highway 165
articles.teasertext: The only state highway in the country specifically designated to serve a cemetery...and nothing more. It's also the only state highway in the country to be partially closed every night.

articles.title: Tower of Wooden Pallets
articles.teasertext: Now replaced by an apartment building, its site remains City of Los Angeles Historic Cultural Monument no. 184.

articles.title: S.N.P.J., Pennsylvania
articles.teasertext: A municipality consisting solely of a Slovenian fraternity's recreation center, established (in part) to get around liquor laws.

articles.title: Spiral Island
articles.teasertext: An artificial island, now destroyed, built from thousands of empty floating plastic bottles.

articles.title: Track 61 (New York City)
articles.teasertext: A secret train platform located below the Waldorf Astoria New York designed for use by U.S. Presidents when they would visit the hotel.

articles.title: U Thant Island
articles.teasertext: An island in the East River with a surprisingly in-depth history for only being 2,000 square feet (190 m2) in area.

articles.title: Truth or Consequences, New Mexico
articles.teasertext: A New Mexico town that chose to rename itself after the Truth or Consequences game show in 1950, then never bothered changing back.

articles.title: War of the Roses
articles.teasertext: The historical rivalry between Lancaster and York. Not to be confused with Wars of the Roses, the historical rivalry between Lancaster and York.

articles.title: Wedge
articles.teasertext: It's harder than you think to construct the state of Delaware with a ruler and compass.

articles.title: Whittier, Alaska
articles.teasertext: A city in Alaska where (almost) all of its residents live in one building: Begich Towers.

articles.title: Winchester Mystery House
articles.teasertext: A house believed to be haunted by the ghosts of individuals killed by Winchester rifles.

articles.title: World's littlest skyscraper
articles.teasertext: The result of a fraudulent investment scheme, it's a four-story brick building constructed in 1920 in downtown Wichita Falls, Texas that has only one room on each of its four floors.

articles.title: Zilwaukee, Michigan
articles.teasertext: "Is this Milwaukee?" "Uh...yeah, it sure is!"

articles.title: Zone of Death
articles.teasertext: The part of Yellowstone National Park in Idaho, where any crime can technically be committed without punishment – but don't tempt fate!

articles.title: Landsat Island
articles.teasertext: A lonesome island with a frankly humorous tale.

articles.title: London Bridge

articles.title: Parasitic twin

articles.title: Rumpology

articles.title: Self-inflicted caesarean section

articles.title: Sleep sex

articles.title: Scrotal inflation

articles.teasertext: Modern reincarnation of necrophilia.

articles.title: Jaxon Buell

articles.title: Jeanne Calment

articles.title: Stubbins Ffirth

articles.title: Phineas Gage

articles.title: Genie
articles.teasertext: A feral child who was neglected by her father and was locked in a room for the first 13 years of her life.

articles.title: James Harrison (blood donor)

articles.title: Abby and Brittany Hensel
articles.teasertext: Conjoined twins with separate heads but joined bodies.

articles.title: Paul Karason
articles.teasertext: An American man known for having blue skin.

articles.title: Hans Langseth
articles.teasertext: A guy who had the longest beard recorded in history.

articles.title: Robert Liston
articles.teasertext: A 19th-century Scottish surgeon who, among other things, performed what has been described as "The only operation in history with a 300 percent mortality rate".

articles.title: Barry Marshall
articles.teasertext: A doctor who, against the consensus of mainstream medicine, drank a vial of bacterial culture to prove that stomach ulcers were caused by bacteria rather than stress, spicy foods, and too much acid as was believed at the time. He won the Nobel Prize for it, too.

articles.title: Alexis St. Martin

articles.title: Lina Medina

articles.title: Billy Milligan

articles.title: Wenceslao Moguel

articles.title: Blanche Monnier

articles.title: Chandre Oram

articles.title: Adam Rainer
articles.teasertext: The only person known to be both a dwarf and a giant.

articles.title: Mary Toft
